22 NEBRASKA STATE DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION PROGRAM State Farm, Dairy Building Wednesday, Februa-y 26. 1919 Address of Vice-President F. G. Caldwell Secretary's Report R. W. McGinnis The Organization of Dairy Cattle Clubs D. H. Propps Dairy Legislation J. H. Frandsen Afternoon Session 2:00 P. M Some Results of Kansas Dairy Experimental Work J. K Fitch Professor Dairy Husbandry. Kansas Agricultural College PROCEEDINGS The Thirty-fourth Annual Meeting of the Nebraska Dairymen-^ Association met in tbe Dairy Building. State Farm, and in the ab - sence of the President. Mr W, H. Ferguson, the meeting was called to ordei at 10:20 A. M. by the Vice-President, Mr. F. G Caldwell, of Lincoln, Nebr * ♦ VICE-PRESIDENT CALDWELL: Ladies and Gentlemen and Mem bers of the State Dairy Association: In calling this our Thirty-fourth Annual Meeting of our Association to order this morning I come to you with no annual address as is usual for the President to have his address prepared and reviews the year's work, but while you have most every one had about all the substitutes the past year you might relish, it is unfortunate that I am forced to appear here for the President. The officers and directors of the Association began last November by instructing the Secretary to send out invitations to all the parties interested and who usually take part in the deliberations of the Asso - ciation seeking their advice and suggestions as to Just what would be the most interesting subjects for discussion at our annual meeting, but about the time the replies came in the epidemic was so prevalent that the meetings of Organized Agriculture were called off. and consequently we were "called off" with the others. In accordance with the law that governs the operating of our Asso - ciation the Secretary and several of the Directors met the third week In January, but having no quorum, and not in a position to transact business, adjourned until some future date when the business of the Association might be transacted. The report of the Secretary will now be heard SECRETARY: Mr. Vice-President and Members of the Dairymen's Association: The report of the Secretary given you here this morning will merely be a short synopsis of what has been accomplished by the officers and directors for the past year, but the real report will appear In the rear book, which would be too lengthy to give in detail here, and furthermore m w« bare only prepared for a one-day meeting, It Is »«Mm£ ip most valuable rtnp of the members should I attempt to gtre

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 23 the report in full, which will appear later, and also something that you can read at your leisure. It is in ho r«>KrPtti»d that our meptim; has been delayed inlil this late dati 1 , and our crowd ncit as large, as usual, an the dairy people always have the largest and, pleased to say, best looking crowds of any of the meetings of Organized Agriculture. Last November the Board decided to make this one the beat pro - gram we ever had in the hisory of the Association, and having made Kuch great progress last year, everyone was getting more enthused than ever, but on account of the influenza becoming so prevalent and the Annual Meeting called off, we were not able to hold our proposed meeting, and in consequence our program went 10 pieces and it was not unlil a short time ago when the Organized Agriculture committee decided to hold their postponed meetings on this date that we were ■Ml to get together and hold a short meeting and prepare a program. This part was an easy task, but to get the speakers to come and help us was the most important matter and difficulty to overcome, and m awhile Prof. Frandsen and the writer used the telegraph and tele - hone quite freely, and while we have not been able to prepare a very long porgram, at the same time we have one that in our own opinion is awfully good and some of the best speakers we have ever had. Now, in regard to the work during the past year, I want to say ihat the Association has made wonderful progress. In fact, I think more has been accomplished in various directions and the officers have had more to contend with than they have for many years back in the history of the Association. You understand, of course, that the State Dairymen's Association is the foundation for other allied associations, such as the Nebraska Dairy Cattle Breeders' Association, the Nebraska Jersey Cattle Breed - ers' Association, the Nebraska Holstein-Friesiau Club and the Ne - braska Ice Cream Manufacturers' Association, and not the least, even if mentioned last, the State Experimental Farm and the Dairy Division under the direction of Prof. Frandsen, 1 want to say has done a great deal and been a wonderful assistance all the time. We have been working to get more cow testing done out in the state, and now have several of them running with success, and that will be sufficient encouragement for others to get started. Another matter that is working out nicely and will make progress is the organizing of Cattle and Calf Dairy Clubs. For over two years we were working on plans to get this going, and seemed to be just so near but yet so far from making progress, but this year we finally got the officers of the State Bankers' Association to meet with the officers of our Association, and after explaining the plans and the merits as well as the benefits, and through the strong talks of Professors Frand - sen and Propps at the meeting, we succeeded in convincing the bankers the plans and proposition were good and would be beneficial to the vicinity, and they appointed Mr. Seymour of Elgin, who was chairman

24 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION of the Bankers' Agricultural Committee, to take hold of this and work with the other bankers and push this, and we have the best prospects of getting this to the front than at any time previous. In addiion to working up enthusiasm in getting cow testing asso - ciations and dairy cattle and calf clubs establshed in various parts of the state, the Secretary's office has been also compiling, and in a very short time will be able to give each member of our Association a statement showing the number of cans of cream produced in Nebraska for the past five years, and will also show the number of cans of cream shipped each month each year for the past five years from every station in Nebraska. We find this most interesting in making the com - pilation for the reason that during the first three or four months of the year the volume is light; then in the months of April and May it increases, and during June, July and August, when the weather is the hottest and the cream the lowest in price and poorest quality, and the farmer most busy, he produces the most cream, and then along towards fall, as his work decreases, his cream also falls oft. and in the winter, when he does not have much for he and his men to do and the price and quality of (ream is the best and higneet, he is selling the least cream. The county agents are all members of our Association, and we are much pieaosed to report that the majority of them are taking quite an interest in dairying. All the county superintendents are also mem - bers of our Association, and from letters received and talks with the school people Indicates there is going to be quite a movement in the schools along the educatiom in dairying. The exhibits at the State Fair were through the efforts of ihe let his work take care of itself in his absence: but we want you all to Dairy Association and had the assistance of the Dairy Division of the State Farm and also the Nebraska C'remery Manufcturers' Assocation. The latter looked after the butter statuary; the men who made the cheese and gave the instructions were from the Dairy Division at the State Farm, and the other exhibits were looked after by Professors Frandsen. Propps and Nevens. All of this will appear in the year book, and we think you will be interested in reading just what was ac - complished, and in fact our butter and other exhibits have become such an interesting feature at the State Fair from its educational view - point that it is becoming more attractve each year. Now please understanu »e are not gong to stop here and come to the conclusion there is nothing more to be done. We are Just getting started and right now where we ought to have been years ago. We are hearing from the people in the interior and western part of the stale who are too busy and expense too much to come to our meetings and visit the dairy division at the farm as you know, a dairy - man is a pretty busy man, and every four years he has an extra day to put in, consequently he la not as a rule able to take long trips and

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 25 know that they are Just as much entitled to know about dairying the people who live close to Lincoln and can come to the meetings It Is the intention of the officers and directors to make every effort this year to hold district meetings, and will be something along the lines the Association did in the year 1913. The Burlington and Northwestern railroads gave the Association a train of care that carried some cows, a good bull and another car of dairy utensils, etc., and we traveled over the line from Verdigre to Harrison and from. Crawford and return to Lincoln, stopping at stations of importance, and it certainly was a revelation to those people out in the state the way the cream shipments have increased from the major - ity of these stations visited and the better dairy cows they have shipped in is subsantial proof they are interested. We are hopng that this can be done again in the near future, and since making the trip in 1913 the automobiles have been increasing In numbers, and a survey made by the writer in going orer the state and talking with the county agents and others, it now looks like we will have to stop at a less number of stations and put in more time and have the people drive to the meetings. There is not a day but what someone out in the state is asking. "When is the Dairy Association going to run another demonstration and instruction train?" The foundation has been laid, for greater dairying in this great state of ours, and with the best of water, climate, cheap land and abil - ity to raise corn and alfalfa most any place in the state, we have the opportunity, and the question is will be to take advantage of it. VICE-PRESIDENT: On account of some of the trains being delayed and our speakers not arriving just on time, we will deviate a little from our printed program and will call upon Prof. D. H. Propps as the first speaker. Professor Propps has charge of the dairy extension work and has put in a great deal of time and hard labor In trying to get the cow testing associations and dairy cattle and calf clubs started, and we know that you will all be very much interested to hear from him. PROFESSOR PROPPS: It is true that I was asked to make an address on Calf Clubs, but it has always been my practice not to ask people to listen to me read a written address, in tact I am not going to say very much either about this subject or any other. I want to say first that we appreciated pery much the assistance and co-operation of the Dairy Associations this year, particularly in the support of the cow testing associations. It would be almost impossible for us to con - tinue this work without the support of this Association. Do not think Nebraska is the only state where cow testing associations get support from the State Dairymen's Association. Last year was the first year we have had any support from the Dairy Association. Now as to the calf clubs, there has been considerable interest in calf clubs in the

26 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION eastern and northern part of the state, the custom being to handle young stuff; the members of the club buying these heifers, keeping them a few months and selling them, and they were allowed the profits they made on the heifers. . The plan is open to criticism for a good many reasons. There has been a feeling among men most familiar with club work that the best plan would be to handle older stuff and work with men of more mature age. A plan of this kind was outlined by the Dairy Extension Service last spring and was approved by the Nebraska State Dairymen's Association and the State Bankers' Association. We hope that in the future the plan will be followed by whatever clubs are organized. VICE-PRESIDENT : In making up our program it was thought we would all be vehy much interested to know about how our neighboring state on the south of us was progressing in dairy circles, and we suc - ceeded in securing the head of the Dairy Division of the Experimental Farm at Manhattan to come up here and tell us all about it. ard take pleasure in introducing Prof. J. B. Fitch, professor of dairy husbnndiy. Kansas Agricultural College who will talk to us on some results of the Kansas experimental work. PROF. J. B. FITCH: In presenting the results of some of the ex - perimental work being carried on by the Dairy Department of the Kan - wis Agricultural College. I have decided that you would probably br most interested in an experiment we have under way in raising dairy heifers. The experiment is still in progress and it is too early to draw any definite conclusion. I only wish to give you some of thp data ob - tained therefrom. Many of the experiment stations have published results on raisin*: dairy heifers, and especially on the cost of producing dairy animals. and in a way this work may be a repetition of previous work on this subject. We have, however, looked at this problem at a different angle. There has been much said about the exclusive feeding of alfalfa to dairy animals, especially in the districts where alfalfa is grown abundantly. It was believed that animals fed on alfalfa exclusively did not develop normally and that it also affected the reproduction of the animals. In addition to this we planned to obtain a comparison of heifers raised on alfalfa alone with heifers raised on alfalfa hay and corn silage, with heifers receiving alfalfa hay. corn slage and grain or a check lot. Twenty-four grade Holstein heifers were divided into four lots of six each. They were placed on experiment as soon as dropped and the lots were balanced as nearly as possible as far as records and breeding was concerned. The lots were divided as follows: Lot 1 -Rreceived alfalfa hay alone Lot 2 — Received alfalfa hay and corn silage. Lot 3 — Received alfalfa hay. corn silage and grain Lot 4 — Received alfalfa hay, corn silage and grain Lots 1, 2 and 3 were bred to calve at thirty months of age and

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 27 lot 4 to calve at twenty-four months of age. This was to study the Influence of early calving on the size and production of the animal*. The grain fed was a mixture of four parts corn chop, two of bran and one of oil meal, and this was fed in the proportion to the sire and pro - duction of the animal. The animals were weighed at birth and at monthly periods through - out their life. Three weights were taken on that many days near the loth of each month and this average represented the monthly weight. On the 10th of each month the growth of the animals was measured by taking the following measurements: height of withers 1 , width of hips, width of pin bones, barrel girth and heart girth. Pictures were taken at birth and at the end of each six months period throughout the experiment. The feed fed to the animals was weighed and recorded as was all salft fed to the animals. Composite samples of feed were taken and analyzed at dlrerent times during the year. Accurate records were kept of the milk produced by the heifers and a composite sample taken for butterfat test during five days of each month and during the first two weeks of each lactation period. Any abnormal condition that developed during the progress of the experiment was recorded to be referred to in drawing conclusions. The above is a brief outline of the plan of the experiment as started in June. 1915. So far twenty-nine calves have been dropped on the several lots. Twenty with first calves and nine with second calve*'. Contrary to our expectations, we have had but little trouble getting ;-.nimals safely with calf. In only three cases have we had 1 any trouble from this source, and this was not confined to any one lot. Two animals were sold as non-breeders. One from lot III. receiving alfalfa hay. silage and grain, we were unable to get with calf, also one lieifer from Lot II receiving alfalfa hay and silage, had one calf but failed to breed the second time. One heifer in Lot I receiving alfalfa hay was rebred five times before getting with calf. All calves were carried full times and the only trouble experienced was the loss of several calves at calving time due to their slxe. This was especially true of Lot IV, which calved at twenty-four months of age. !x>t I— Alfalfa hay 10 Lot II— Alfalfa and silage 6 Calves Av. birth weight lbs. 85.1 90 Cows weight lbs. 920 988 Weight of calf per cent 9.25 9.10 Mt III Hay, silage and grain. 8 89.4 1117 8.00 (30 mil.) :,ot IV Hay. silage and (?rain . r> 91.4 M 9.4 (24 mo.) 28 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION The following Is a table showing the average birth weight of calves on the dlxerent lots along with the average weights of their dams at freshening and the percentage of the calf's weight to that of the cow. It will be noticed that the calves In Lot I were lightest in weight, as were their dams at freshening time. The weights of the calves In the other lots were practically the same. The animals in Lot HI were heaviest at calving time, but it is interesting to note that their calves were smaller in proportion o the weight of the dams than In any of the lots. It Is not always the animals in the best condition that drop the ■oat thrifty calves. No other difference was noticed in the calves of the several lots other than the difference in the weight. In body de - velopment the measurements taken thus far show Lot III to be the largest in weight, height and width. They are heavy boned and do not show the quality of the other lots. Lots I and II have grown more ■lowly and perhaps will not reach the height nor width of Lot III. The heifers In Lot IV, calving at twenty-four months of age. have not reached the height of the other lots, but they are deep and broad In body. The amount of feed eaten can be measured by the cost of feed to the time of freshening. NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOClATIO> ■ Feed Cost for Milk and Butterfat for Different Lots Heifer First Second At two fresh freot years ening eniuf No. year yeai Lot 1 45.35 I1.0S 30.3 cenu .72 21.1 cenu Lot II 35.65 Lot 111 57.65 .85 22.7 cents .75 1\)1 cente Lot IV 4».74 It will be noted that the heifers in Lot I, fed alfalfa hay exclusively- produced milk and (at at a much higher feed cott than those in any other lot. The heifers in Lot II, fed alfalfa hay and silage, produced milk and fat at the lowest feed cost The results obtained so far on this experiment would warrant the following statements: 1. The exclusive feeding of alfalfa hay bus had no effect upon the breeding power of the animals up to this time 2. The feeding of alfalfa hay alone to dairy cows was more ex pensive and produced poorer results than the other methods of feed 3. Alfalfa and silage are more desirable for body development an cost of products than alfalfa alone. Good animals can be raised by thi 4. The full fed lot calving at twenty-four months of age hav given very favorable results, but the smaller size and slower maturing might warrant breeding later. Another experiment of interest to dairymen, especially to those in western Nebraska, is an experiment we have conducted over a peruxl of three years comparing corn, cane and kafir silage for milk pro duction: The results of feeding trials by the Dairy Department of the Kan «•» State Agricultural College show results in favor of .sorghum crops as compared with corn for silage when fed to dairy cattle. In over half of the counties of Kansas a greater yield of cane or kaflr can be obtained with greater certainty than when corn is used. It waa a common sight during the summer of 1918 to see field after field of corn completely dried up in contrast with the green appearance of fields of cane and kaflr. The sorghums are more resistant to drouth, and while their yield is cut down, they have the faculty of living through dry periods and continuing their growth when rain does come. A 27-acre field of corn which was the best prospect for a crop we had ever had on the Dairy Department farm up to July 15 of last sum - mer produced 97 tons of silage when put into the silo the middle of A.utj«. This is a yield of 3.6 tons per acre. An adjoining field of Kansas Orange sorghum put into the silo late in September produced 10 tons of silage per acre. Covering a period of four years on the Agronomy Bat the college, the average yield of silage crops was 11.88 tons of per acre, 11.8 tons of kafir, and IS tons of cane per acre. This n* good bottom land which is most suitable to corn.

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 31 i In feeding trials with dairy cattle, covering three years, it was found tbat corn ullage wag 1 per cent more valuable than kafir silage, and kaflr silage was 10 per cent more valuable than can silage tor milk production. When the amount of milk produced per acre was' con - sidered, however, the cane silage led the corn and kaflr on account of the greater yield. Using the average yields given above for corn, cane and kafir. an acre of cane would produce 30,000 pounds of milk when fed in a dairy ration, an acre of corn 22,000 pounds of milk, and an acre of kaflr 21,670 pounds of milk. While corn is our greatest silage crop, cane and kaflr have proven to be only slightly less valuable for feeding dairy animals and can be raised with greater certainty in most of the counties in Kansas and in the southwest. Knowing this, it would seem advisable for dairy farmers to at least plant a part of their acreage to sorghums for silage. One factor which has a gr.eat Influence on the value of cane and kaflr for silage is the time at which the crop is cut for silage. It fre - quently happens that immateure cane and kafir is put into the silo when the com is ready to cut. Tne sorghums should not be put into the silo until practically mature. When the grains are so hard they cannot be crustier between the thumb and finger the crop will be sufficiently mature that a good sweet silage will result. Green immature sorghums will make acid silage which is less palatable. In many seasons the crop may not have matured sufficiently when the danger of frost is reached. It is best to run the risk of a frost rather than to put the crop in when green. After a frost, however, the crop had best be put into the silo at once. VICE-PRESIDENT: While he is not on the program, he is always here with us just the same, and will not take up any time to intro - duce a man whom you all know and love, so will ask Professor Frand - sen to tell you the situation in regard to the legislative session at present. Mr. Chairman and Association: No more important meeting to - day than the Dairymen. Just so you may be sure of what you are going to have this afternoon, I am going to ask Mr. C. T. Graves, leader on Jersey, to speak this afternoon. Please stand up. Another man; he may have had a number of years of work in his line, but I do not think I would be foolish to call to this part of the country. Mr. Munn, acting as associate editor in Kansas Dairy Farm, will speak. Not so good looking as Mr. Graves. Please stand. Last but not least, a man of household word in any work. When we first tried to get him here, we received a curt telegram it was im possible for him to come; dated ahead two weeks. So when in Omaha a short time ago, I happened to get his promise if he could come he would wire. We received his wire saying he would come. Mr. M. D. Munns of Minnesota. Exhibit A are exhibits we have received bj Mr. M. He will convince you that the saying, "polished tops are not on cheap furniture," is trie.

NEBRASKA DAIRVMKN'S ASSOCIATION COMMITTKK ON LKGISI-AT1ON: The Committee on Legislation consisted of Professor J. H. Frandsen, chairman; H. A. Morrison and E. W. Frost. Professor Frandsen submitted details of a bill which the committee had prepared so that Nebraska dairymen may have opportunity to get free tuberculin testing and reimbursement for the animals reacting. He strongly urged all dairymen of the state to get behind this bill, particularly calling attention to the necessity of get ting in touch with the legislators from their respective sections, so that there may be no chance for this bill failing of passage at this session of the legislature. He thought this bill of far reaching importance so far as the future dairy industry of the state is concerned. The details of the bill as prepared by the committee are given below : For an act to comply with the terms of an act of congress of the 1'nited States, making appropriations for the department of agriculture for the fiscal year IMt, approved October 1. 1918 relating to reim bursement for destruction of tuberculous animals, providing procedure in connection therewith, to provide a bovine tuberculosis fund, to ap - propriate same and to declare an emergency. Be It Enacted by the People of the State of Nebraska: Section 1. Assent is. 1 hereby given to the provisions of an act of congress entitled, "An act making appropriations for the department of agriculture for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1919. approved October 1, 1918, and the good faith of this state is hereby pledged to provide sufficient funds in co-operation with and supplementary to payments to be made by the secretary of agriculture with respect to compensating the owner of tubercular cattle destroyed when in the discretion of said secretary of agriculture and the livestock sanitary board of said state. It shall be necessary. Section 2. For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this art there is hereby appropriated out of the general fund of the state of Nebraska the sum of $75,000, or so much thereof as may be neces - sary. The funds herein appropriated shall be placed by the auditor of public accounts and the state treasurer to the credit of a fund to be known as the bovine tuberculosis fund, and warrants not exceeding the amount herein appropriated shall be drawn by the auditor upon certiflcater, presented by the livestock sanitary board, and warrants so drawn shall be paid by the state treasurer. Section 3. Hereafter all cattle shipped into this state, except those shipped in for immediate slaughter, and all cattle shown at the Ne - braska State Fair, may in the discretion of the livestock sanitary board be tested for the disease known as tuberculosis under rules and regula - tions which the secretary of agriculture and the livestock sanitary board shall from time to time prescribe; provided, however, in addi - tion to the above test, said board, or its duly authorized agent, may order a retest within sixty days after the original test. Section 4. Said livestock sanitr.ry board shall make necessary rules

THIRTY FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 33 and regulations to carry into effect the purposes of this act, and any regulations so made shall be published in a newspaper, or in as many newspapers as said board may deem necessary, or they shall be posted in not less than five public places, and such publication shall be deemed legal notice to all persons. Section 5. Authority is hereby given to said livestock sanitary board to regulate or prohibit the arrival in or departure from the str.te. or any portion of the state, of any such exposed or affected animals, and at the cost of the owner or owners thereof to detain s-ich animal found in violation of said regulations or prohibition. Section 6. Whenever any owner or owners of dairy or beef animal:) in this state believe that any of said animals owned by him are in - fected with the disease known as tuberculosis upon written request made to the livestock sanitary board, said board shall send its agent, who shall be a duly licensed and experienced veterinarian, to test the animals of said owner for the disease known as tuberculosis, at the ex - pense of said state. If it appears necessary for the control or eradica - tion of such disease that any animal or animals found infected should be destroyed, they shall be killed and compensation shall be paid the owner thereof; provided, however, that in no case shall payment by the state of Nebraska be more than thirty-five dollars for any grade animal or more than seventy-five dollars for any pure bred animal. The maximum valuation herein provided shall be exclusive of any compen - sation paid or reimbursement made to the owner or keeper of said tuberculous cattle by the secretary of agriculture or its agent for the destruction thereof as compensated by said act of congress referred to in section 1 of this act. No payment by way of compensation shall be made by the state of Nebraska unless the owner has complied with all lawful quarantine regulations, and that no payment made by the state as compensation for any tuberculous animal destroyed shall exceed one - third of the difference between the appraised value of such animal and the value of the salvage thereof. Section 7. Before any animals infected with tuberculosis shall be ordered killed, they shall be appraised by a representative of the bureau of animal industry of the United States Department of Agriculture, and a representative of the state. If the representative of the department of agriculture and the representative of the state shall disagree as to the amount of the appraisal, or if the owner refuses 1 to accept the ap - praised value, the animal shall be appraised in accordance with the laws and regulations of the state in which animals are destroyed un - der section 152, Revised Statutes of Nebraska for 1913, as amended by section 1, chapter 11, Session Laws of Nebraska for 1915. In the ap - praisal of tuberculous cattle, due consideration shall be given to their breeding value as well as to their dairy or meat value. Section 8. When any dairy or beef animals have been destroyed pursuant to this act, the agent of the livestock sanitary board in charge shall take reasonable precautions to determine prior to his approval

NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION 34 of vouchers in which compensation therefor is claimed who is the owner thereof, and whether there are any other liens outstanding against sai danimal. If it appears there are outstanding liens, a full report regarding same shall be made, and shall accompany the voucher. Every such report shall include a description of the lien, the name of the person or persons having possession of the documentary evidence thereof and a statement showing what arrangements, if any, have been made to discharge the lien outstanding against the animals destroyed, of which the agent of the livestock sanitary board in charge may have knowledge. Section 9. Whereas, an emergency exists this act shall be in full force and take effect from and after its passage and approval, accord- Ing to law. ELECTION OF OFFICERS It was then moved by Mr. C. E. Morse of Lincoln, and seconded by several members, that we proceed with the election of officers, ex - plaining the reason for his desire to elect the officers at this time was on account of many of the members having to leave early in the after - noon, and if waited until after the afternoon addresses it would make it 30 late and only a few of the members would be left to transact the After some discussion of whether to hold the election before the recess was taken for dinner, or immediately after, the matter was put to a vote and the motion carried, there being 39 in favor and 4 against. and accordingly Vice-President Paldwell declared the motion carried. It was decided to, by motion, to elect officers for the ensuing year for the Association, and the nomination of officers was in order. On first motion, duly seconded. Mr. Jacob Sass of Chalco was nom inated for President, and motion carried. Mr. C. E. Morse of Lincoln was nominated for Vice-President, and upon motion duly seconded was duly elected. For the office of Secretary and Treasurer, which had always been following nominated for Directors for the ensuing year: C. H. Gustafson Lincoln. Nebr held by the same person, Mr. J. E. Palm was nominated, and upon motion made and seconded was elected unanimously The matter of the election of Directors was then taken up and the H. A. Morrison College View, Nebr E. C. Swanson Stromsburg, Nebr. Prof. J. H. Frandsen State Farm. Lincoln. Nebr. J. C. Fraieur Bellevue. Nebr Upon motion duly seconded these Directors were elected by unan imons vote. There being no further business, a recess was taken for dinner. with a request that all return at 2:00 P. M.

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 35 HEARTS AND JERSEYS Complying with your request for a writeup of the film show in con - nection with the State Dairymen's Association meeting, will say that inasmuch as moving pictures are rapidly becoming quite a factor in bringing home certain lessons in an educational way, I thought that if it were possible to secure one of the films on some good dairy subject, it would prove a happy surprise for the assembled dairymen. In taking the matter up with the various associations, I found that it was pos - sible to secure the splendid Jersey film entitled "Hearts and Jerseys" for this occasion. I knew the Jersey breeders would greatly enjoy this treat, and other breeders present would share in their Joy with the as - surance that at some other time the Jersey people would enjoy with them a film close to their heart. This film was loaned by the American Jersey Cattle Club of New York City, to whom the Nebraska Association Is, of course, greatly indebted for the treat. The picture emphasized in quite a striking manner the Important characteristics of Jersey cattle and carried with It enough sentiment and human Interest to be fascinating to those who saw it. The story is that of a young man starting out in life under the handicap of poverty, ignorance and misfortune. However, he had the determination to overcome these obstacles and turn them into success. The particular discouraging features which he had to overcome were ■ mortgaged and run-down farm stocked with "red cows." whose milk was "too thin" to show any return of profit to the owner. The inspiration for better things came from an ambitious neighbor who attributed his own success to the possession and management of a head of Jersey cows. It is almost needless to say that the change in methods of farming and the addition of pure breds to take the place of the common "cows brought to this young farmer his Just share of financial success and assured him an enviable social standing in his community. J. H. FRANDSEN THE SPIRIT OF 1918 In keeping with the demand of the times and the resources of the state, the Nebraska Creamery Butter Manufacturers' Association pre - sented at the Nebraska State Fair a magnificent piece of butter sculp - ture, entitled "The Spirit of "18." This piece of butter sculpture was similar to one presented last year, entitled "The Spirit of '76." The model for this year's exhibit was taken from the federal food department's poster, which is well known to most everyone, and shows three figures, one, a grandfather with a basket of corn, his sturdy son with a sheaf of wheat and his grandson with the box of vegetables.

36 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION The figures were made in life size and required over one thousand pounds of butter. Several tons of ice were used to keep the piece securely chilled and firm. To say that this was a great attraction would be putting it mildly, for many thousands of people came in especially to view the splendid work of art. There is an important lesson to be learned from this exhibit, and undoubtedly it was grasped by most of the people who witnessed it. First of all, our government has given us a picture which holds up to all the importance of food production. It reflects the

37 THIRTY-FOrRTH ANNTAI. CONVENTION true patriotic spirit of the food producer, placing him in the front rank with the large and important matters concerning this great conflict. Nebraska is by nature liberally endowed to play a most Important part in this r eat food producing movement. With our fertile land* and splendid furms we are great food producers. Here we find corn and alfalfa, hogs- 1 , cattle and butter produced in large quantities. NV - braska each year produces a vast amount of surplus food. Butter is one of the most vital elements and one of the most im - portant for us to produce. It can be marketed easily, as it is a con - densed food. In its production we use to the greatest advantage our rough raw materials, literally, we condense the cheap raw forages of our farms' into this highly nutritious food. Nebraska is annually producing about fifty million pounds of butter per year. We are encouraged to double this production, which we can easily do, and by so doing we will not only render a great service to our country, but a!so will enrich ourselves and our state. Let us be led by the "spirit of '18" — produce more food and help •Win the War." THE 1918 STATE FAIR EXHIBIT The production and conservation of food were the keynotes of th 191S State Pair exhibit of the Department of Dairy Husbandry. In large booth near the center of the building demonstrations in the ma ing of cottage cheese were given throughout the day by two exper from the dairy department. The great amount of interest shown i this work was sufficient evidence that the people of Nebraska are be ginning to realize the threefold possibilities of this product: the pre uration of wholesome appetizing and economical dishes; the utilizatio for human food of such of the skim milk which heretofore has bee but little used for this purpose; the agreeable substitution of th product in the diet for the more expensive meat, thus permitting fo eign shipment of greater quantities of the latter. Another feature attracting great attention was the presence four war winning dairy cows which graced the new box stalls in th east wing of the dairy building. The cows which had this honor a doing their bit to help win the war by producing more human food tha any other cows in Nebraska. Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha. record 24,741 pounds of milk and 1.053 pounds of butter, owned by Nelso Bros., Stromsburg. and Hope's Daisy Cornucopia, record 20,130 pound of milk and 720 pounds' of butter as a two-year-old, owned by Woodlaw Dairy, Lincoln, were' exhibited under the auspices of the Nebraska Ho stein Friesian Club. Across the aisle were two remarkable Jersey cow owned hy H. C. Young of Lincoln, Torono's Iris and Mermaid's Pane Wax. the latter having a nine months' record of 846 pounds of butte These cows were selected for exhibit by the Jersey Breeders' Associ tion of Nebraska. Both state associations had booths from which the represetnatlves distributed literature regarding th«lr breeri*.

THIRTY FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 39 Opposite the booth which formed the headquarters of the State Dairymen's Association, the Dairy Husbandry Department had a display of moving charts and pictures which stilt further emphasized the value of skim milk for human food and also the type of cows which Ne - braska needs to increase production, and to do it at a lower cost per pound of product. The indispensable qualities of milk as a food for the young were emphasized and the public urged to consume more dairy products. At - tractive models showing possibilities in the preparation of ice cream, which Is now considered a valuable food as' well as a delicious dessert were also displayed. DAIRY INDUSTRY REPRESENTED AT NEBRASKA STATE FAIR J. H. Frandsen The importance of one or Nebraska's leading sources of wealth, that of the dairy industry, was very forcibly emphasized by the dairy exhibit at the Nebraska State Fair held in September. 1918. The general management and supervision of this exhibit was unde the direction of K. L. Murray, president of the Nebraska Creamery Im provement Association; R. W. McGinnis, secretary of the Nebrask State Dairymen's Association, and J. H. Frandsen, head of the Unive slty Dairy Department, representing the allied interests of the De - partment of Dairy Husbandry of the University of Nebraska, the diffe •■nt dairy breeds associations, the Nebraska Dairymen's Association, th Creamer}- Improvement Association, and the United States Dair Division. Perhaps the most impressive sight on entering the dairy buildin was the "Butter Statue." occupying a prominent central position. Th artist, J. A. Wallis, using the figures of the "Spirit of '76." made butter, but modernized under the title "The Spirit of '18," represented the spirit of the state of Nebraska both in production and conserv tion of food material for use at home as well as "over there." Th first of the figures, a youth, was offering a case of fruit and vegetable the second, a man of venerable age. was holding a basket of ears corn, while the third, a man of middle life, had gleaned and was hoi ing across his shoulder a sheaf of grain. The dairymen, in payin tribute to these industries, have recognized the spirit of co-operatio for the welfare of all. The spirit of conservation was again emphasized more strongly, from the practical standpoint, in the booth given over to the cottage cheese demonstration of Professor Krause of the United States Dairy Division, and Professors Luithly and Rovner of the Dairy Department of the University of Nebraska. A large audience was present most of the time to hear the lectures and see the demonstration of the making and use of cottage cheese as a war food. Comparatively few people realize the importance of conserving the
THIRTY-FOURTH AXNTAI. CONVENTION' 41

42 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION skim milk from Nebraska's dairy herds' now being directed into less profitbale channels and in some instances channels of almost total loss. If this product from Nebraska's more than 700,000 dairy cows was made into cottage cheese and used to supply the protein now furnished in beef would release more than half a million steers for use of our sol - diers and sailors over sea. The Jersey Breeders' Club emphasized the excellencies of their breed by having on exhibit two of Nebraska's record Jerseys, Toron's Iris, the senior champion Jersey of 1917, and Mermaid's Fancy Wax having a nine months' record of 846.25 pounds of butter. Both animals were furnistoed through the courtesy of their owner, H. C. Young of Lincoln. Nebraska. In addition to these model approaches to Jersey perfection, the club also had a representative in their booth to answer questions, dis - tribute literat'ire and discuss topics of interest to the breeders of Ne - braska. The Nebraska Holstein Breeders' Club was represented by the champion Holstein record cow of Nebraska, Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha. owned by Nelson Bros, of Stromsburg. Nebraska, having a years record ot £4,741.5 pounds of milk and 1,053.4 pounds of butter. Hope's Daisy Cornucopia as a junior three-fear-old with a production of 20.129.9 pounds of milk and 720.3 pounds of butter was furnished for the exhibit bf the Woodlawn Dairy of Lincoln, Nebraska. Bulletins- 1 of the high record Holsteins, together with other valuable information about the breed were distributed by an expert Holstein breeder from the club's booth. The Ayrshire and Guernsey rattle Clubs do not have organizations in Nebraska, but Professor Propps was instrumental in arranging and decorating tmall booths to represent the interests of these two breeds of cattle. The Nebraska State Dairy Association booth, in charge of the sec - retary, Mr. R W. McGinnls. was no less attractive and interesting. Large charts were used to point out by means of statistics and com - parative diagrams the efficiency of dairying in the production of human ;nd an mal food as well as value in conserving soil fertility. These charts and those of the University dairy exhibit were planned and pre pared under the direction of Professor William B Nevens, Messrs. Eli Duncombe and J. W Hendrickson assisting in the preparation. Last, but by no means least, in importance, was the booth of the Department of Dairy Husbandry of the University of Nebraska The center of attraction at this booth was the automatic multiplex machine containing twenty-fo-ir large charts which were kept changing giving only time for the passers-by to read the striking points of interest and observe the illustrations pointing out the value of milk products in comparison with other articles of diet often costing more for the same food value. In addition, there were series of charts on ban, and milk house plans showing proper arrangement of buildings for conyeni
THIRTY FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 43

44 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION ence and sanitation; followed by charts showing some of the notable representatives of the leading dairy breeds, finishing the set with illus - trations of the University of Nebraska dairy herd, including a large picture of Katy Gerben and her eleventh calf. Katy Is one of the foundation cows at the Nebraska station and has produced milk which if valued at present prices would be more than $11,000. Another attraction of more than passing interest was the case of models showing some possibilities in ice cream making. The booth was largely in charge of Professor Nevens, Mr. Dun - combe and Miss Fagan, who were kept busy handing out publications and registering those interested in university bulletins. The decorations were in keeping with the spirit of the times, and in addition to the patriotic bunting and ferns used the dairy depart - ment booth had on exhibit the service flag of the U. of N. Dairy Club, having twenty-one stars 1 . Mr. Chittenden and the Louden Company added much to the success of the general exhibit by furnishing the material for the box stalls and booths. Judging from the interest shown by the spectators the dairy in - dustry in Nebraska has reached the degree of development where it is an important factor in the wealth of the state. Plans are now al - ready under way to make the exhibit for next year larger and better than ever before. NEBRASKA HOLSTEIN-FRIESIAN CLUB HOLDS ANNUAL MEETING The Nebraska Holsteln-Friesian Club held their annual meeting at the Fontenelle Hotel, February 11, 1919. The following officers were olected for the ensuing year: President. H. C. Langan. Vice-presidents, D. M. Hildebrand and Jas. R. Foree Secretary. Dwlght Williams. Treasurer, E. W. Frost. Directors, Dr. B. B. Davis, Arthur Nelson. NEBRASKA'S HIGHEST PRODUCING HOLSTEIN J. H. Frandsen, Lincoln, Nebraska Nebraska is near the head of the list in dairy production. Her latest achievement is in the production by Nelson Bros., Stromsburg, Nebraska, of Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha No. 148726, with a record of 1,053.4 pounds of butter and 24,741.5 pounds of milk in 365 days. This cow has one of the fine, long records — one that makes her now the champion cow for best annual production in Nebraska. Below are tabulated some of her records. Record 7 day 275 day 30 day 3«5 day Age pounds pounds pounds pounds

Mo. butter milk bitter milk butter milk butter milk 4 g 19.25 456.6 471.81 11,138.6 4 9 28.88 683.1 116.63 2,595.6 124.26 2,664.8 1.05S.4 J4.741 .5 7 1 30.04 641.5 These records show a steady and consistent increase and place Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha No. 148726 In front rank of Holstein* while yet a young tow. The above records were made on ordinary grain ration such as is nvatlable on any Nebraska dairy farm. It consisted of an average of 20 pounds of grain mixture daily, which consisted of bran, oate, oil - meal, cottonseed meal, a little corn and corn meal. In addition to this. f*e was well sheltered, given plenty of good water, and sufficient exercise. She is a cow of wonderful constitution and is able to use any and all feeds which are given her for consumption. Glancing over her an - cestry, it is small wonder she is a wonderful producer. Her dam has a record of 23 pounds of butter in 7 days and her Rire. Dutchland Colantha Sir Inka, has 64 A.R.O. daughters, 13 above 30 pounds of butter in 7 days, and one above 388 pounds of butter In 7 days. She has a daughter with a record of 20 pounds butter in 7 days at the age of 3 years, 2 days, showing that she transmits her producinf power to her offspring, which in the greatest distinction a high prc ducer can claim. Nelson Bros., breeders of this animal, are also Nebraska products, being born, raised and educated In Nebraska. They are graduates of the School of Agriculture, State Farm. Lincoln, Nebraska. They have always been interested in scientific agriculture and by application of scientific principles, together with patience and perseverence. have built up a herd of Holsteins at Stromsburg. Nebraska. The abilly of these men to produce a cow like Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha No. 148726 is a tribute to their training and ability This cow is one of the many good ones Nebraska has produced. Indeed. Nebraska can be pretty proud of her dairy cows and progressive dairymen. Frandsen For the first time in several years, a Jersey cow, Mermaid's Fancy Wax 359225. owned by H. C. Young of Lincoln, Nebraska, has captured the state butter record of Nebraska. Fancy Wax produced 15,155.2 pounds of milk, with an average test of 5.54 per cent, making a total of 844.56 pounds butter. This remarkable record makes her the g.'ate champion of all breeds, beating Nelson Bros.' Holstein, Yankee DeKol DeYong Colantha. with a butter record of 1,051.9 pounds butter by 3.8 pounds of butter. Mermaid's Fancy Wax combines a much sought combination of high production, with a highly developed conformation, as she was also a first price winner, register of merit class, at the Nebraska State Fair for 1918. The following table gives her official and total production by months: This phenomenal cow began her record at 5 years and 187 days of age, and in spite of the severe handicaps of war conditions and scarcity of special feeds, was able to "go over the top" in good style. During the month of February it became necessary, Mr. Young reports, to thaw her frozen silage with hot water, and this caused her to bloat so badly that it was necessary to remove all feed and water for two days. FRANDSEN, Nebraska Department Dairy Husbandry WILLIAM DEMPSTER HOARD Willirm Dempster Hoard was born at Stockbridge, N. Y. in 1S36, and died at his home in Ft. Atkinson. Wisconsin. November 23. 1'Jls Mr. Hoard served as governor of Wisconsin, 1889-1890; member of nurut;ry business in Wisconsin. 1865-70. In 1870 he began the publi - cation of the Jefferson County Union, conducting a dairy department which soon attracted much attention and led to the publication of Hoard's Dairyman, which became a recognized authority, world-wide, on ull matters relating to the dairy industry. Mr. Hoard served as governor of Wisconsin, 1889-1891; member oi the board of regents, state university, and as president of various state and national organizations whose objects were better methods in agri - culture and especially as relates to the dairy industry. Mr. Hoard attended the first annual meeting of the Nebraska Dairymen's Association, held at Fremont in December, 1885. He took an active interest in the proceedings, of the meeting and was elected an honorary life member of the association. Mr. Hoard attended the annual meeting of the Dairymen's Associa - tion held at Lincoln in 1905, and delivered an address on "Rural Life Problems" at an evening session of Organized Agriculture. In addition to his duties as editor of Hoard's Dairyman, Mr. Hoard conducted a model dairy farm in the immediate vicinity of Ft. At - kinson, where he kept a herd of some forty registered Guernsel cows, each one of the number a model of well bred, profitable cow. In the passing of ex-Governor W. D. Hoard our nation loses one of its most highly esteemed and useful citizens, and agriculture and especially the dairy industry, one of its most intelligent and forceful advocates. RESOLUTIONS Members of the Nebraska Dairymen's Association meeting this 26th day of February at Lincoln. Nebraska, do petition the committee ap - pointed by the Department of Agriculture to formulate definitions and fix standards for the dairy nnd other food products and do earnestly
50 William D. Hoard, Editor, Governor, Dairyman

51 THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION tuition said committee that they do not change the fat and moisture batter standard which ia now recognized and enforced, namely 80 per cent fat and 16 per cent moisture, which always has keen and is now the ruling and lawful standards in all foreign countries which are lar»« producers of dairy products. We know that to make a change in said standard will not only cause millions of dollars of lows to the producers of dairy products, but will also handicap the American industry in their home and foreign markets We also urge that they do not require a special branding for butter made from cream which has a part of the lactic acid reduced by neutralizing, for such branding will stigmatize the largest percentage of the butter manufactured in this country. We believe that both from a producer's and consumer's standpoint the present basis of fat in butter and definition of butter are practical anl ample. Whereas 1 , it is now scientifically demonstratel that milk and its products are absolutely necessary for the growing child and indispen - sible for the adult and thus vital to national prosperity and human welfare; Therefore, be it resolved, that in the readjustment of our indus - trial and business relationship no effort should be spared in conserv - ing the dairy industry, and we urge all business as well as civic organi - zations to aid in the great work of developing and conserving the dairy industry. Resolved, that all members of the Dairy Association use every effort to secure the enactment into law of the bill now before the legis - lature entitled "An act to comply with the terms of an act of congress of the United States, making appropriations for the department of ag- ricnlture for the fiscal year 1919, approved October 1, 1918, relating to reimbursement for destruction of tuberculous' animals, providing pro - cedure in connection therewith to provide a bovine tuberculosis fund. to appropriate same and to declare an emergency." ASSOCIATION HISTORY By Mr. Bassett The Nebraska Dairymen's Association was organized in the" city of Lincoln, in the month of February, 1885. At this organization meet - ing S. C. Bassett was named president and H. H. Wing «ecretary Other officers were elected and a constitution adopted, but no ad - dresses' were made and no annual report or year book published. The first convention and, as it was called, the first annual meeting, was held at Fremont, December 9-10. 1885. At this first annual meeting, J. Dixon Avery was named president and H. H. Wing secretary. The first annual report or year book cov - ered the Fremont meeting and was the first one published.

NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION 52 At the December meeting in 1886. W. G. Whitmore was named president. Hence, S. C. Bassett served as president from February, 1886, to December, 1885. J. Dixon Avery served as president from De - cember, 1885, to December, 1886. W. G. Wbitmore served as president from December, 1886, to December, 1887. It seemed best, that as the secretary was required to edit the an - cember to January; this when Organized Agriculture meetings were uual report, which covered the proceedings of the annual meeting, he should hold office a sufficient length of time after the close of the meet - ing to enable him to edit and publish thereport, hence tht rules,' were changed so that officers elected at an annual meeting held in Decem - ber should take their office on the first of the succeeding April. Later the date of the annual meeting was changed from December to January -this when Organized Agriculture meetings were first arranged — and the date in the month for the annual meeting to be determined by the board of directors. Each president, and all officers, serve a portion of two years, but in making up a list of presidents, (or instance, it hardly seems neces - sary to mention both years in which each served, as J. Dixon Avery, 1885-1886. Hence I adopted the plan of giving the names in their order of service, assigning each a year: S. ('. Bassett, 1885; J. Dixon Avery. 1886; W. G. Whitmore, 1887. I also sent Professor Frandsen, for deposit in the University Farm library foh safe keeping, the original record book containing the consti - tution and the proceedings of the organization meeting of February. 1885, this in the handwriting of H. H. Wing, the secretary. Let me suggest that the association have this record book bound in a cloth cover, same color as our annual reports and printed on the outer cover "Nebraska Dairymen's Association, Original Record of Organization." This will help to preserve the book, which has great historic values. If you are to publish in the year book a list of ex-officers of the asso ciation you may think well of the suggestion to include the proceed - ings of the organization meeting. S. C. BASSETT REPORT OF FIR8T DAIRY ASSOCIATION MEETING, HELD AT LINCOLN, FEBRUARY 24, 1885 History of the organization of Nebraska Dairymen's Association as copied from the original minutes in the handwriting of H. H. Wing, secretary, and now in possession of the society. Pursuant to a call published in the Daily State Journal and other newspapers of the state, several gentlemen Interested in the develop - ment of the dairy interests of Nebraska met in the Academy of Music. Lincoln, February 24, 1885, for the purpose of organizing a State Dairy - men's Association. S. C. Bassett of Gibbon was called to the chair and

53 H. H. Wing of Lincoln was made temporary secretary. After some pre - liminary remarks eleven gentlemen signified their willingness to Join the proposed organization. On motion. S. C. Bassett. H. H. Wing and J. W. Liverlnghouse were appointed a committee to draft a constitution and by-laws, after which the meeting adjourned until 9 o'clock on Wednesday. February 25 Lincoln. Feb. 25 1885. Pursuant to adjournment the meeting was called to order by Chan man Basset t. The committee on constitution and by-laws reported the following: Constitution This organization shall be known as the Nebraska Dairymen'* Association; its objects shall be the promotion of the dairy Interests of the state. S«M-. 1 Any person who shall pay into the treasury of this association one dollar shall be a member one year, and be entitled to alt the privileges and immunities thereof, and any person wh > shall pay into the treasury five dollars shall be a life member thereof, and shall be exempt from annual payments. S.M The officers of this association shall consist of a president vice-president, secretary and treasurer and five directors, who shall be chosen from its members, and as many additional vice-presidents as shall be deemed advisable, chosen annum':. 1 at the regular annual meeting, and shall be the officer-; for ttie year next following their election, and until their successors shall be chosen. S« Sec. 1 The president, secretary and directors .-hall constitute a boarl of managers, who shall manage the affairs and control th ■ business of the association. A majority of the board at a regu laily called meeting shall constitute a quorum to transact business. Sec A meeting of the association shall be held annually on the second Tuesday of December, for the election of officers and for holding a convention at such place In the state as shall be designated by the board of managers. Sec. 6 Public notice of all regular meetings of the association shall be given by the secretary at least twenty days before the meet - ing, and a written or printed notice shall be mailed to every member thereof. All meetings of the board of managers shall be called by the president or secretary, or by any three of the board of managers, notice of which shall be given to each of the members thereof at least five days before the meeting. Any vacancy which may occur in the board of managers may be filled by appointment, by the board, for the unexpired term tor * hich such officer was chosen. Sec. 7

NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION 54 Sec. 8. The place of business of this association shall be where the secretary has his residence. Sec. 9. These by-laws may be changed or amended by a majority vote of all members of the association present at any annual meeting. On motion the constitution as reported was adopted, after which the following persons became members of the association Life Members Hon. L. S Coffin, Fort Dodge, Iowa J. Dixon Avery, Fremont. Nebr. Callender) WHY TESTS VARY Possibly there is nothing connected with the creamery business that creates more dissatisfaction than the varying of the tests from time tn time. Especially is this true where the hand separator is used. It is only reasonable that the creamery patrons should watch the cream tests Jealously, as the amount of money they receive for their product is based on the amount of fat they produce. A slight variation in the test will change the patron's proceeds quite materially. A high test, other things being equal, means a large check; while a low test means a small check. If the test varies from week to week or from season to season, the patron naturally becomes suspicious, and his suspicion gradually ripens into dissatisfaction with the creamery. He reasons with himself that as the creameryman does all the testing, the variation in the test must necessarily be the fault of the creameryman. He know* that the milk that he separates comes from the same herd of cowc. These cows are few the same and are usually milked by the same person. Therefore, it is only reasonable that if the test varies. Mm patron will blame the creameries for the variation. Dissatisfaction of this kind has probably broken up more cream - eries and injured the dairy business more than any other one thing in connection with the dairy business. The writer has been engaged in the creamery business directly for a great many years and he has also been engaged in the creamery business from an educational standpoint. Therefore, we might say that our knowledge of the creamery business is fairly accurate. We must confess that we have never yet found any proprietor of a creamery who knowingly and willfully attempted to de - fraud the farmer in the way of cutting tests. If he wishes to continue in the creamery business, it would be suicidal on his part to attempt a deception of this kind. If the creamerymen test correctly, which wp believe they do in practically all cases, then we must look for some other cause for the variation in the test. There has been some valuable work done by Prof. Hunziker of La - fayette, Ind.. on the Causes of Variation in Testing, from which we are quoting extensively in this article. Work of the same kind has been done in Denmark also. Variation* in Tests Are Due to Variations in Richness of Cream. If the cream is tested correctly and if the tests of different lots of cream from the same patron vary, then these variations must be the result of variations in the richness of the cream. The experience of intelligent and observing dairymen and the results of careful expcrj-

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 61 mentK conducted at the Purdue and other experiment stations clearly and conclusively show that there is a great variety of factors and con - ditions which control and may change the richness of the cream. Since the creamery receives the patron's cream after it has been separated, the creamery has no control nor power over these factors. These fac - tors and conditions influence the richness' of the cream before the cream leaves the farm. Cream from the Gravity Can: Where the skimming of the milk is accomplished by the use of the gravity can. it is a physical impossi - bility to produce cream of exactly the same richness from different skimmiiigs. It is impossible to so operate the bpoon, ladle or skimmer, as to remove the same amount of milk with the cream each time. Where the skim milk is drawn from the bottom of the can it Is equally impossible to so gauge the operation as to leave cream of the same richness in the can at each skimming. Gravity cream, or cream ob - tained by gravity skimming, is U-erefore sure to vary in richness and the tests of different lots of such cream must vary accordingly. Cream from the Farm Separator: It is comparatively easy to con - vince the average, fair-minded patron thai the tests of gravity cream must vary because of the variations in the richness of the cream ob - tained by this method of skimming. B'lt this is not so where the farm separator is used. Every one familiar with this machine, must acknowl - edge that the farm separator is one of the most highly perfected pieces of farm machinery in use. A piece of apparatus of such a high degree of perfection is expected to do nearly perfect work. The farm sep - arator is. therefore, expected to produce a cream uniform in quality or ricqness. This expectation, too, is a reasonable one. The farm sep - arator does produce the same richness of cream from different skim nringb' provided, however, that it is adjusted properly; that it is oper - ated in strict accordance with the directions which accompany it; and that the richness, condition and temperature of the milk and the pro - portion of water or skim milk used to flush the bowl to amount of milk separated, are the same. The Cream Screw: The ricness of the cream obtained from any farm separator is primarily determined and regulated by the cream screw. The centrifugal separator has two main outlets; namely, the skim milk outlet located near the periphery or outer wall of the bowl, and the cream outlet, located near the center of the bowl. When the milk enters the revolving bowl It is separated into two layers 1 , the skim milk and the cream. The skim milk, being heaviest, is hrown against the walls of the l>owl where it escapes through the skim milk outlet. The cream is drawn toward the center of the bowl where it rises and is discharged through the cream screw or cream outlet. The cream screw is a small threaded bolt with a very minute opening. This bolt can be turned so as to move the opening nearer or farther from the center of the bowl. When turned toward the center it de - livers richer cream because the nearer the center of the bowl the richer

62 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION Is thp rrfam W'ni'a timed MM from 'ho renter il deliver- thinner cream. because the farther from the renter of the howl, the less som plete the separation of thp skim milk from the cream. Effect of Richness of Milk on Richness of Cream: The richer 'lie milk, the richer will he Ika cream With the cream screw set to de - liver a certain and definite richness of cream and all other conditions normal, the separator will deliver a definite ratio of skim milk and cream. This ratio varies according to the way the cream screw is 1 set. Under average conditions it may be about eighty-five to fifteen. That is. for each one hundred pounds of milk separated the separator deliv - ers eighty-five pounds of skim milk and fifteen pounds of cream. If all conditions are the same, this ratio of skim milk to cream remains con - stant. Changes in the richness of the milk cannot alter the proportion of skim milk to cream delivered. No matted how rich or how poor the milk, each one hundred pounds of milk will yit Id eigrty-five pounds of skim milk and fifteen pounds of cream. But because practically all of the fat goes into the cream, the cream will contain more fat from the separation of rich milk than from that of thin milk. This fact is graphically illustrated in Figure I: The above illustration conclusively shows that, all other conditions being he same, 3 per cent milk produces 20 per cent cream. 4.3 per cent milk produces 30 per cent cream, and fi per cent milk produces 40 per cent cream. Changes in the richness- of milk cause changes in the richness of the cream. Any condition, therefore, that affects the rich wess of the milk will also influence the richness and the test of the jream. Conditions that May Cause Changes in the Richness of the Milk: During the early summer months the milk is usually comparatively low in butterfat. This is caused by such factors as the freshening of the cows, change from dry feed to succulent pasture and a natural and in - herent tendency of the cows toward a decrease in he richness of their milk in early summer. Toward fall and early winter the opposite is the case. The advanced state of the period of lactation and the change from succulent to dry feed cause the milk to become richer in fat. It is obvious, therefore, that in the fall and winter the cream test tends to be higher than in spring and early summer. Again, it frequently happens' that even in winter there is a sudden drop in the cream test. This may be due to the fact that some of the cows yielding rich milk dry up or that some cows come in fresh or a new animal may be brought into the herd. The seasonable variations of the richness of the cream may be reduced by turning out the cream screw a trifle in the fall and by turn - ing it in some in the spring of the year. Effect of Rate of Inflow on Richness of Cream: The greater the amount of milk passing through the separator of a definite capacity per hour, the thinner will be the cream. The skim milk outlet of the bowl is 1 constant. It can discharge so

The Proper Temperature for Separation: The best practical tem- perature at which to separate the milk on the farm is about 90 degrees F. The milk is never in better condition for separation than immedi- ately afer it is drawn. It then has a temperature of about 90 degrees' F to 95 defrees F. THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 67 CHOPPED ALFALFA VS. BRAN IN GRAIN RATION FOR DAIRY COWS The problem of reducing the cost of the ration for the dairy cow is of much importance. Where roughage may be substituted for a grain or a by-product concentrate, the cost of the ration is likely to be de - crea.-ed. Throughout a large part of tha western half of the United States aiialta hay is abundant and comparatively cheap when calcu - lated on its protein or energy units. In th? form of alfalfa meal it may be shipped inco a large part of the country east of the Mississippi river at r cost much less per ton than the cost of mill product of like feeding value. The North Platte Substation of the University of Nebraska has con - ducted an experiment to determine whether chopped alfalfa may be substituted for wheat bran in the dairy cow grain ration of 4 parts corn. 2 parts bran and 1 part oil meal, and the effect of such substitu - tion on the performance of the cows. The first test extended from D« - i-ember I. 1916. to January 30. 1917. During this time the cows were fed about 30 pounds of silage per head daily and had access to a rack containing alfalfa hay. The second test was begun March 1, 1917, nnd closed May 30, 1917. The cows were fed silage and alfalfa hay Throughout the test and had some grass during the last few weeks. Tlir amount of grain was based on the milk flow — one pound of grain for 3 or 4 pounds of milk. Six pairs of cows were selected for each test. Each pair was matched as closely as possible in respect to breed, lactation period, pre - vious record, milk flow, percentage of fat, and other factors that would be expected to affect production. One cow from etch pair was put into Group A. the other cow into Group B. The six cows of Group A were fed a grain ration consisting of 4 parts ground coin. 2 parts 1 bran and 1 part oil meal during the first period of 15 days, while the six cows of Group B were fed a grain ration consisting of 4 parts ground corn. 2 parts chopped alfalfa and 1 part oil meal. During the second 15-day period the A group received the alfalfa ration while the B group re - ceived the bran ration. The test was extended through four 15-day periods, during two periods of which the cows of Group A were fed the bran ration and two periods the alfalfa ration. The cows of Group B were fed in a similar manner, only that when the cows of Group A were getting the alfalfa ration those of Group B were getting the bran ration, and when the cows of Group A were being fed the bran ration those of Group B were being fed the alfalfa ration. During the third period of the first test one cow in Group A, being fed the bran mixture, went off feed for a few days, and during the fourth period another cow of Group A. being fed the alfalfa mixture, dropped in production for a few days. As one cow was off when on bran and the other when on alfalfa, these devciencies do not influence the final results.

68 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN S ASSOCIATION During the second test one cow became sick She and her mat were taken out of the test, leaving only five pairs of cows. Results of the First Test The six cows in Group A while on the bran mixture during two 14 - day periods gave 3.972 pounds of milk containing 144.3 pounds of butter - fat, and lost 32 pounds in weight. The same six cows while on UN alfalfa mixture during two 15-day periods gave 3.952 pounds of milk containing 138.7 pounds of butt erf at. and gained 223 pounds in weight. The six cows of Group B while on the bran mixture during two 15 - day periods gave 4.244 pounds of milk containing 158.4 pounds' of buttei - fat. and gained 128 pounds in weight. This same group of cows while nn the alfalfa mixture during two 15-day periods gave 4.332 pounds of milk containing 163.6 pounds of butterfat and gained 1 pound in weight Bringing together the results from both groups we iinri that the twelve cows while eating the bran mixture during two 15-day periods produced 8.216 pounds of milk containing 303 pounds of hutterfat and gained 96 pounds in weight. The same twelve cows while on the al falfa mixture during similar periods produced 8.284 pounds' of milk containing 302.3 pounds of butterfat and gained 224 pounds in weight Results of Second Test The five cows in Group A while on the ration of corn, brar oil meal during three 15-day periods gave 7.430 pounds of milk tcining 250 pounds of butterfat. and lost ?, pounds in weight The five cows while on the ration of corn, alfalfa and oil meal during 141day periods gave 7.147 pounds of milk containing 245 pounds o terfat and lost 52 pounds in weight The five cows of Group B. while on the ration of corn, bran and oil meal during three 15-day periods 1 gave 7.239 pounds of milk con taining 241 pounds of butterfat and lost 125 pounds in weight The same five cows while on the ration of corn alfalfa and oil meal during three 15-day periods gave 7.309 pounds of milk containing 239 pounds of butterfat and gained 68 pounds in weight. Combining the results from the two groups we find that the ten cows while being fed bran with corn and oil meal during three 15-day periods gave 14,669 pounds of milk containing 491 pounds of butterfat and lost 128 pounds in weight. The same ten cows while being fed alfalfa with corn and oil meal during three 15-day periods gave 14.456 pounds of milk containing 484 pounds of butterfat and gained lfi pounds in weight. Two Tests Combined Twenty-two cows while being fed a forage ration of silage and al - falfa hay. and a grain ration of 4 parts ground corn, 2 parts bran and 1 part oil meal during an average period of 75 days, gave 22.886 pounds of milk containing 794 pounds of butterfat and lost 22 pounds in weight. The same cows during a similar period and under similar con <J it ions, and fed the same ration excepting that chopped alfalfa replaced

HIRTV KOIRTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 69 ) ivhilt I ■a in ration gave 22.741 pounds of milk rontalning 78« nn«l RHitiPd 240 pounds in weight ing these tests with twelve cows for Iwo months an4 ten cows hopped i.lf;ilf;i was s-ihstituted for bran in thf ree mi Liiuliiril dairy grain ration of 4 parts ground corn, 2 parts bran and part oil im-al without any appreciable unfavorable effect. The slight of 14.". pounds in milk and 7.5 pounds in butterfat production the alfalfa was being eaten was more than overcome by the gain : pounds in the weight of the cows. It is evident that in these nlfalfa was fully equal to bran. If thes><e results are the same a> und in general practice, then alfalfa fed in this manner has th» feeding value as bran.

Connecticut, left it. It had been believed since 1840 or hereabouts, the time of the famous chemist. Liebig. who was really the agricultural chemistry, that the essential constituents of an dequate diet were proteins and such carbohydrates as starch and sugar nd fat and certain mineral salts. Liebig believed that if we had as much knowledge as accurate chemical analysis could give us regarding [hose constituents of foodstuffs that we had the data necessary for the alculation of such proportions of wholesome, natural food as would, it »d to an animal, induce good nutrition. Atwater believed that was so late as the nineties. He believed it to such an extent that he spent all of his energies in the perfecting of an apparatus into which he could put a man and determine, when he was at rest, how much energy he was metabolizing, how much heat he was giving off, how much carbon dioxide he was breathing out. In other words, he was determining as accurately as he could, and he did it with a nicety that left little to be desired, how much energy a man or an animal — no. not animals, it was left to Dr. Armsby of Pennsylvania to do the same thing with animals — he determined how much energy a man needs in various states of activ- ity.
