76 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION \ • luirn- ' ; literature regarding the composition of American IimkIsiuIT.- < .11 will laffd Bulletin 2S ol the Department of Agriculture, in which iin analysis ot Alwater was tabulated, you will find that he purchased i\i.;ihing lrriii oystors on the halt shell to peas, and determined how much enoigy ihere was in them how much protein there was in them, and the value of a pound of the article in both energy yand protein. He believed confidently that energy, protein values and digestibility were iho three factors which determined what we should do with the food ft* in the matter of combining it so as to obtain good nutrition New. as a matter of fact, it was the animal husbandry men who ill st nuliztd thai ihal was not the whole story. Most of you possibly i'o net rtalize that, but that is where the suggestion came from. In this countiy, the United States has been for a century, more than ;i eentui\. a land of plenty. We have had available for human nutiition all the cereal grains; such vegetables as beans and peas; we had all the products of the field and garden; we had the dairy industry, we had the meat industry, all available, and at very moderate prices, up to recent times, and until recently every foodstuff I have listed was available to the humblest citizen of the poorest income. It is not to be Miaiviled at that when mm wen eating such a variety of foodstuffs as 1 have just listed and from so many different sources that it should have entirely escaped observation that the protein content, the energy content and the digestibility was not the whole story in nutrition. Accident took care in a general way. accident took care of the chance, rather, took i an- of all the mm into which we might have fallen had our diet been of a more restricted character. Theie are certain diseases peculiar to faulty diet, one of those is Known as beriberi. Ii has been common for centuries, nobody knows l'o\. n>any centuries, among the rice eating peoples of Hit 5 Orient. The Filipino laborer in the city, who buys polished rice and eats it with tish; the Jaianese laborer; the poor Chinese: many people in India, have i ver attained the size we have attained in this countiy; never have • ssed in liteiature and science, any of the achievements in which we have progressed, as have the people in Western Europe progressed We have been free from that dii-ase in this country. To my knowledge it has never occurred here. Now, another disease of dietary origin is scurvy. It used to be dis ugly common on the long sailing voyages of the past which occu - pied weeks or months, where the sailors were restricted to a diet of mm biscuit and salt pork and they came down with scurvy. If they pwed a ship which could suppiy them with fresh vegetables or orange juice the scurvy would disappear in two or three weeks and they would be < n '.heir feet again. It was recognized that the disease was caused by faulty diet, beriberi has been associated with the faulty diet of the P'.ople I have talked about. There is still another type of faulty nutiition which we never suf fered from in this country until recently. For centuries in parts ot

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION Italy and parts of Franc pellagra has bten more or less of a scourge among the poorer elements of populations. IVllagra did not appear in the United States, or at taart it was not recognized, until 1807. In 1917. just ten years later, the statistics show us that we have no Ian UMH 165.000 people afflicted with pellagra in ihe United States. Th.-y a.-. nearly all grouped in a few states ilown south. That has long been supposed by shrewd ciitical obser\ers !o be the result ol eating a diet of corn. Well, coin has nothing to do with it. That is well MMMMMd now. but they didn't know it then. These people were li\ing largely on a dish known as polenta, which was made from corn, and the;, suffered from this disease, pellagra. There is still another disease which is believed by many to be a disease referable to faulty diet, nobody knew how, and this is rickets. You go into some of the poor districts in the cities, notably the Colum - bus Hill district in New York, where the children. i>ruc;icully 100 pi . cent, have crooked legs ami crooked backs, and they are hunchbacks ;i i they grow up into deformed adults or die in infancy, and the infant m> : tality i» excessively high. One-sixth of the population of the city cf Baltimore is black. Among that one-sixth there is -lit per lent of the total death r;;t< drath rate ;ri,m tubfi vulosi:- as the white people ol Doston da We ha / no excessive death late from tuberculosis among the whites in B.Ut UK me all diseases referable to faulty diet, Ikw no No < ne knev. to wl-.ai exieni bacteriological infection might pla.. ■ Hit. The animal husbandry man prod >ing pork and producing meat and producing milk was not feeding his animals such a variety of foo'.lsi'ii"? as to lead invariably to a moderate degree of success. The anininl husbandry man. particularly the man who fed pigs, was in many making a failure of it. That has been recognized by nfcjMl husbandry men for a good many years, that pig raising presented some problem? The pig haw been about as much abused as any animal I know of. Ha has been in many cases on farms where the fanner ■ M M ;:v;ue if tin principles of successful animal husbandry. The pig hM been !:ep- in :■. dry lot for a considerable period of time, frequently and fed on corn plus some by-products cf the milling industry. mm tuberculosis The white people cf liultiiuui •

78 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION Now. it came to be recognized, perhaps twenty years ago. by a few .lirewd animal husbandry men that that practice was a failure from an economic standpoint, but they did not know why. From 1890 on, if you inspect the literature which was published by experiment stations in this country, you will find that they were en - gaged here and there, particularly Professor Henry at the University of Wisconsin, Dr. Armsby, and a few other men. in the feeding of this or that concentrated protein shuppleuient, such as the by-products of the cornstarch industry and the wheat-starch industry; feeding this and that concentrated by-product of the packing industry as supplement to this or that grain. to see which one gave the best results. Now, that ought not to have been so. It the information on which they had drawn was actually true, that the protein content, the energy content, the digesti - bility would tell you the food value of a product, it should never have been necessary to spend all the time and money in conducting expensive experiments with animals to try and find out which combinations gave the best result As a matter of tact, there were many failures in pig raising, and pig raisins m unprofitable on many farms. Every one ot you, if you will think ovu your experience on poorly managed farms. will visualize a pen full of pigs that were much older than they should be for their size, runty in appearance, hopelessly stunted and that never could be brought out by any animal. You can still find it in n not feeding them right. system ol feeding into the profitable any pa the country They a Now. that was recognized by \ly a few people. They began, how ever, in the late nineties to teach in tlie agricultural colleges that cf tain combinations of food gave better results than certain others The was no theory in it. Perhaps as long ago as 1890 Dr. Babcock. wh< you all know so well, used to go to the annual meetin le agricul tural chemists and poke fun at Atwaler when he would get up and tell about some new analysis he had mad.- ;tnd it used to annoy Atwatei considerably to have him question the value of the results which he pre sented. In other words, he was skeptical as to whether these data were worth what they -were purported to be worth. Dr. Babcock was always interested primarily in dairy chemistry- and, although Dean Henry was anxious to have him take up the study of nutrition problems, he never would do it, and he told me that the reason why he did not do it was that it would never be solved and the chances of success were so small he had better let it alone. So he stuck to dairy chemistry and I regret to say that I think, by doing so, by failing to go into the field of nutrition and spending twenty years of his life in that, he kept back progress very materially, because he is a sufficiently shrewd man to have taken this thing up and have done perhaps more with it than any other man could have done. The beginning of progress in nutrition studies was in 1906. In that year Professor Hart went from Geneva out to the University of Wiscon sin to take charge of the department of agricultural chemistry. He

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL. CONVENTION 79 wanted to do some research and experiment work, and he consulted Dr. Babcock as to -what would be a good proposition to take up and Dr. Habcock suggested that he test out this question as to whether diet made up from different sources, different foodstuffs, made just alike in the protein content and the energy content and the digestibility, and fed monotonously to animals would give equally good results; that he did not believe they would; that he had argued that with Atwater, but that Atwater was not in a frame of mind to argue it, and thought it was silly and a question not worthy of serious discussion, and had said so. So. Dr. Babcock suggested that they make up three rations, one de - rived entirely from the wheat plant, and another from the corn plant, and another from the oat plant. They would use the grain and the straw and the blade, and make them all alike, and they would select some heifer calves and feed them on these three rations, just alike In the chemical analysis, and see what happened to those animals. And that was done. Professor Hart followed his suggestion and that was done. The experiment had been going on (or perhaps a year and a half when I firm saw those animals and there was beginning to be some difference in their behavior by that time. Those that had the wheat plant as a sole source oi nutriment did not look so well as the others, but they all looked fairly well: there wasn't anything very marked. A great many men would have given it up that point, but they thought it wbb worth while to keep it going. When I went to Wisconsin in 1907 I was shown these animals and Bay that the wheat animals were not doing so well as the others. They asked me to participate in that investiga - tion and see whether or not by some magic methods in physiological chemistry we could not find out what was the matter with the wheat ration that it did not make the animals thrive. I took hold of the job and did the best I could for a few months, but 1 gave it up as a bad job. It was a complex thing. Nothing appeared in sight that could be done to throw any light on that question. At the end of the summer of 1908 those cows produced their first offspring and there we saw some very remarkable differentiations in the well-being of these animals. Many of you aie familiar with this. It was published in Bulletin 17 of the Wisconsin Experiment Station. The wheat-fed animals were looking pretty dejected at that time. Their coats were rough and their hair stood the wrong way. They did not look well at all, and the calves they produced weighed about, between 40 and 50 pounds, a little over half as much as they should weigh. A calf should weigh 75 to 80 pounds at birth, yet these wheat-fed animals produced calves that weighed only 40 or 50 pounds. Every one of them was born a month before it should have been and every one of them was dead when born. The oat-fed animals looked pretty well, but they produced their calves a little too, noon. Every one of them was about as big as it should be, weighing be - tween 70 and 80 pounds, and every one of them was either dead when born or died within 24 hours after birth.

80 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION A very marked contrast to that result was what we got out of the coin-fed animals. Understand, gentlemen, these animals were eating the entire plant. The calves produced by those corn-fed cows beat anything you ever saw. Every one of them was vigorous and was on his feel light away. There was a most surprising differentiation in the quality of the feeds, due to the quality of the breed, because the chemical analysis showed them to be alike in their food value and yet they were not alike when a biological test was applied. 1 became more and more convinced that the situation had to br studied from another standpoint, so that even in the first year I was out there I began to study the problems of nutrition from another view - point; namely, to determine first of all what is the simplest ration on which you can get an animal to grow. That was the proposition which Dr. Eabcock had studied. That was a good thing and I counseled with him on the subject. He said. "Go ahead. If the experimentation won't pay the bill, I will pay it." But he did not have to pay it. because it did not amount to very much in those days. The first few years the thinj, .vent on pret'v well Now that was ■ logical conclusion, the business of finding ou: what wps the simplest diet on which an animal could live and otherwi 1 -'* finding out wh.:t hr actually had to have in the way of ehemica! sub stances ,\.ld miner;. I r<!( nit-nts, and how much he should eat in Older ti thrive. Thut wo>il<! grive u? some place to stand in order to prog: ihe more complex cause <f failure in the more complex rations. It took five or six years, and it was only about 1912 that we btgM to get a clew as to what was the matter with these purified food mix lures. You make a purified food of starches, sugars, fats, inorganic Mill und you have everything there that you could have -digestibility nnl everything else. They were appetizing — we made them appetizing We put sugars in there to make them sweet, we made them sour, and they lasted all right, and yet an animal would not lire any longer on such lood mixtures than they would if you gave them no food at all T'i;r was food for thought and sufficiently so that we kept up the exp.-n mental work there for five or six years without ever getting an animal to grow. We used for that purpose a small, convenient laboratory ani - mal which would eat so little that we could afford to do an •lateral* piece of chemical work on every piece of substance that we t hough i should go into the ration. For that reason we selected the tame, do - mestic rat as the subject to be worked on first. Now, it turned out this way: In addition to these well recognized and long recognized constituents ->i the diet, starches and fats and pro tiens, you have got to have two other things, and those two other things are of the class that a man named Funk in 191 it designated as vitamines. He had a little accurate data and he wrote away ahead ol his experimental data, and he prissed it in certain respects. His wot'; was excellent as far as it w<v«t. but he inisse^ it on certain things. There are but two of fttose substances, one »f which is beat applied

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION ■ is most, obtainable in the fat ol milk and is found associated with a number of fats, the mom important fats being butter fat, egg yolk fat and the fats out of the glandular organs of an animal, such a? liver and kidneys. These fats would permit growth when put into a diet, pro vided the diet was right in every other respect, but the diet had to have a second unknown thing in it and that second unknown thing i a thing which cured this disease, beriberi. .now. we had some suggestions on that point before 1912, but I wi not burden you with all the details of our experimental history. It is very entertaining story, but it is too long to give you here this after noon. What I want to impress upon you is that there are two un known things, one of which is associated with certain fats, but neve found in any vegetable fats. It is present in butterfat and egg fat am liver fat and kidney fat. but it is not present in any vegetable fat. Th other unknown substance is never associated with any fat. And, b 1913, we had it down to that point wthere we knew those two things Now, for that reason I have differentiated on these two substances am named one of them fat soluble A and the other one water soluble 1 because we did not know anything about the chemical nature and it better not to name these things until we know something about them In organic chemistry and physiological chemistry we have an elaborat system of nomenclature which is logical; the name usually shows som thing about the properties of the thing, and it is a wrong policy, an one which tends to confuse scientific progress, to give a thing a nam which turns out to be a misleading name. So I have not employed th term vitamine suggested by Professor Funk, but suggested these su stances by the first two letters of the alphabet. A and B, with th soluble attached as a prefix. A diet consisting of starch or sugar or other hydrates and fat soluble A. plus this second substance, which will cure a rat or any other animal when he is in a state of malnutrition, paralyzed, constitutes an adequate diet. Those are the things you must have in a diet. Now. let me show you how that knowledge led to marked progres in the interpretation of the cause of failure and success in the more com plex ration. We began this working hypothesis in 1913; namely, tha if a diet consists of these things I have named, of well known. Ion known constituents, that diet plus these two unknowns, and nothin else required in an adequate diet, then we ought to be able to take single, natural foodstuff, such as whole wheat or rolled oats, or corn, o rye. or barley, or peas, or beans, and find out by. not by any chemic method, but by a systematic study of feed trials, what is the troub with such natural foods that they do not induce any growth. We have tried for years. Davis and I fed rats on whole wheat alone, the kernel alone; we fed them on the corn kernel alone; we fed them on th oat kernel alone, and we nevr found any feed that would induce the slightest bit of growth in a young rat. Now, the question was, why? Obviously, if an adequate diet, consisting of proteins and starches and

82 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION sugars and fats, plus these two unknowns, and wheat or oats or i-orn. fails to make an animal grow, it was because there was something thr matter with one or more of those food factors. And so we said. "WV will take wheat as a starter and feed wheat with a good protein." In another case we tabulated the inorganic content of milk. 100 grams ot milk in one column, and the inorganic content of wheat in another, and we saw there was a lot more mineral energy, except in magnesium, in 100 grams of milk than in 100 grams of wheat. So we made up a salt mixture which when added in certain quantities in loo grams of wheat would give it a content closely similar to milk, on which the young ani mal would grow. In a second ration we had another feed that was made up of all butterfat and of all those elements, and curiously enough it did not "carry on" any whatever. Our working hypothesis was wrong, and it was absolutely wrong. So we assumed that there must be at least two factors in the wheat kernel that were simultaneously of poor quality, or something the matter with two or three factors which was con - tributing to the failure of animals to grow on the wheat kernel. So we made a second series of experiments and in those the interest mg result was observed that where we made two purified food additions to wheat, and one of those was a salt mixture, the animals would grow; and where you did not put salt in, then they did not grow. It didn't make any difference, provided we put the suitable salt mixture in. whether the second addition was butterfat or whether it was protein. The animals grew on two of those combinatoins, the wheat in two pan fled additions. The next step. then, was to feed wheat with three puri - fied additions. I might say that we observed these animals on two purified additions until they died, and what we found was that they ap peared a little over half grown and then they never grew any more They were acting more or less like a lot of pigs on farms where they are poorly fed. They stopped growing before they should have stopped Those animals never produced any young. Instead of living three years they were all dead in eight or ten months, where they should have lived three years if they had been well fed. Now, we made a third experiment with whe^t in which we fed wheat plus a good protein, plus a suitable salt addition; and there we had a complete ration from infancy to old age, right up at the normal rate, and they produced the normal number of young, beginning at the youngest age at which the female rat is fertile, namely, about 120 days, and they almost never failed to successfully wean the young. In other words, there are three things wrong with the wheat kernel. One of them is, its inorganic content is unsatisfactory. The second is. it lacks enough of that unknown substance furnished by butterfat. The third is. its protein is of poor quality. Now, you may ask me how a protein can be of poor quality and I am going to give you an illustration which I have used a number of time* recently to show how we can have good proteins and poor pn> teins. A protein is a very complex molecule. When we take a protein

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION ■ into our bodies we digest it and we take it apart and then we absor those parts from nut digestive tract and we go to work and put then together again in a new arrangement and make our tissue protein Now. what happens is this: The proteins vary greatly in the propo tion of these different digestive products. And so this is an illustration o the problems which an animal meets in its protein nutrition: Suppos I have in my hand a block of printer's type to set up that when inke and clipped into position and printed on a piece of paper it will prin something that we can read. Then I take a block, which corresponds t my muscle proteins, and print them and look at them and what you read is "Jack Sprat could eat no fat; his wife could eat no lean." Now I take as food proteins a block of type which when slapped on a piec of paper prints. "Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers." Now suppose I take those two blocks of type apart and try to set one up intc the other. In the first place you need two fs in the first line of th Jack Spratt story and you haven't got any in the Peter Piper story. You have got a big excess of p's in the one case and you don't need ver many in the other. You cannot transfer one of those blocks of type t the other. That is exactly a parallel. The proteins in the vegetab world, many of them, are not very good. They contain the wrong pro portion, just as these letters, which makes it impossible to use them efficiently in growth. When we came to do the same type of thing, the systematic feed ing addition in experiments, with single and multiple food additions, with the grain kernel, with the oat kernel, and rye and barley and peas and beans and millet seed, and I don't know how many — we found that seeds as a class are pretty closely similar, that they all have to have the same thing done with them, with one or two exceptions. Millet seed is a little different from the other seed. But in a general way you have got to do the same thing with one seed as with another in order to make it complete from a dietary standpoint. I know now that there are only three mineral elements you have to add to any seed to make it complete. Those are calcium, the principal element in lime, and the two elements which are present in table salt, sodium and chlorine. You must add all three of them, any pair of them will not do; and you must add the same three for any seed that we have studied. Every seed lacks a sufficient amount of that unknown substance in butterfat to induce normal growth and prolonged well - being. And I want to tell you what happens to an animal when you deny him a sufficient amount of that substance. I have been trying for a couple of years to get a good photograph of an animal which has been selectively starved for that thing. I did not succeed until last week, and I did not have time to make a lantern slide to present It here to show you. When an animal is selectively starved for one of these un - knowns, namely the fat soluble A and the water soluble B, he gets paralysis. So does a rat or a chicken or a pig get paralysis when you make him run short of that particular substance In hi* diet Now, when

84 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION ».• -. |p«-iivfly star\e him for that substance thai is in the hutrerfai. yim eel an entirely different net »( s\ni|ifoms and failures occurring in the course of four cr fi\<> weeks. And if there is an entire lack of it in Mi diet you notice that the tissue surrounding his eyes (which normally are very bright and prominent and bead-like in the rat) swell up and within three or four days you can notice that he can't get his eyelids open any more; his eyelids are badly inflamed and there is more or less hemorrhage: you can see little specks of blood around his eyes. And in the course of three or four weeks from that time, if you do not t'.o anything to save him. he will die. Now. you can bring him to within three or four days of death from a lack of this unknown substance that butterfat is so rich in. and then give him an adequate amount of butter - fat and his eyes will clear right up. You can cure him in the first few days by giving him a little butterfat. but, if you let him go. within three or four days of death, his eyes will look normal except that the color is faded out. and sight is gone. Now, by searching the medical articles pretty carefully I have been able to find at least three or four cases wher? that disease has occurred as a human disease. One of those rases was reported in 1906 by n apanese physician named Mori, and he noted among a class of Japanese who were living on a diet of leaves and seeds and roots and tubers and meat- -in other words, they did not take dairy products, due to a time 01 drouth — where the available supply failed, he noted approximately four hundred cases of children who had this eye trouble, and he described exactly this thing that we had found experimentally before we knew anything about his results. We had proved experimentally that it re suited in an animal as a result of a specific lack of the substance it' butterfat. so that we could cure an i.nimal's eyes right up with butterfat Now, the things that make me know that he was dealing with exactly the thing I am telling you about is* that he said that the only thing In knew — and he was a very shrewd physician to see it — the only thing he knew that would cure that eye trouble in these children was to give them chicken livers. The fats out of a glandular organ of an animal will cure that eye trouble the same as butterfat. but you can give them any vegetable fat and you would not cure that eye trouble, no matter how much fat you gave them. He could have cured these eyes, understand, in the same way we cured these animals. In Denmark in the last five years have been reported about forty cases among rural children who were fed exclusively on separator skim milk. In other words, the centrifugal machine is a very efficient skim - mer and these rural children had been fed on skim-milk because there was such a good market for cream and butter. So forty cases around Copenhagen and Denmark have occurred where the children had this eye trouble and the physician has noted where they put them over on whole-milk that their eyes cured right up. And I could tell you of other eases which were bona fide cases of the curing of this eye disease by butterf.t.

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION ■ To proceed to the next subject: It is not only impossible to nourish Kn animal on the one side, but you can make a mistake and failure in the growth of the animal unless he gets a suitable salt supply. Now, a pig out in the lot eating nothing but corn, and eating more or less drie<l wheat, will grow a little, but he will never be much of a pig. You can feed him on five or six different kinds of seeds and get him where he cant get anything else- and that is a pretty important thing when you aie conducting experiments- and you will never get an animal to grow 10 any appreciable extent on a diet of seeds. Now. in very market contrast stands what you tan uo with mix - tures of leaf and seed, and when you come to think over your human experience you will find that only those animals make a success of a strict vegetarian diet that eat the leaf and the seed itself. It is an easy matter to make a good diet with mixtures of leaves and seed, but you have got to take more leaf than mankind will ever eat. because leaves aie not palatable, are not acceptable to him except in very few cases. We are not prepared, because of the limited capacity of our digestive tracts, to eat very much leaf, and that is not a very good plan. It is further impossible to make mixtures — and I would like your un divided attention while I say this — you can't, in our experience, make a mixture of seds with tubers, potatoes or sweet potatoes, with roots, such as beets and potatoes and radishes, with lean meat, such as round steak and meats of that sort. Put those all together and if you limit an ani - mal to that food m.ixtun: you will never make an animal out of him. Now. v, hat are we going to do abcut it, and wnat does this tell us with regard to nutrition? There are just two protective foods — and 1 would like to have you listen to that term and take it away with you- - there are just two classes of foods which I have recently designated as "protective foods." They are protective foods because they make good the dietary deficiencies of this list of things I have just mentioned. :uch as tubers, roots and lean meat. Those protective foods are: first of all. milk (that is the best one there is). (Applause.) The second best is the leaf of the plant. There are two classes of human beings in the world. You classify them upon the basis of diet. One of them is trying, and has been from time immemorial, to make a diet which is satisfactory out of leaven, seeds, fruits, tubers, roots and meats. The Chinese, Japanese, Filipinos — many of the tropical and sub-tropical peoples — have been trying to do (hat thing from time immemorial. The Japanese and Chinese eat four or five times as much of the leafy portion of the plants as we do over here. We have practically gotten out of the habit of eating leaves in any appreciable amount. They are not very good. We do not like them in any appreciable quantity. They are too bulky lor us to consume and there is good reason why we should not attempt to plan our diet so as to make such a liberal use of the leaves of plants as will make th* leaf our protective food. Consider what those people are who have tried U> make their diet

86 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION through centuries on leaves and seeds and fruits and tubers and roots and meats. Not a single nation that has restricted itself to such a diet ha* ever come to the front in in matter of human achievement in any field of activity. They all stand— the Japanese are the best, but what are they? A distinctively undersized people, a short-lived people — a Japanese man of 60 years is as old an a well preserved man of 90 in this country. Their infant mortality is distressingly high as compared with what you find it in the worst districts of the whole United States. They are a people who have failed to achieve anything like what they could have achieved if they had a better diet. You can go all over that portion of the world where such dietary habits prevail and you will find peoples who are the subjects of vassals; they are the peoples who multiply in considerable numbers, but whose life is short, who are inefficient, of low mentality, warped by peculiar religious prejudices which ruined them. even if they had the at length to do something. They are a failure from the standpoint of living a normal human life. Who are the peoples who have achieved, who have become large, strong, vigorous people, who have reduced their infant mortality lower than the peoples who have used the type of diet first described, who have the best trades in the world, who have an appreciation for art and literature and music, who are progressive in science and every activity of the human intellect? They are the peoples who have patronized the dairy Industry. (Applause.) The statistics can show — they are not very accurate, but they mean something very definite — that we have been taking for many years in this country. I don't know how long, about eighteen per cent of our total food supply in products of the dairy, as milk, as butter, as cheese. and as cream. That particular dietary habit has made us what we are. That is the protective food which has made good the deficiencies of whatever else we chose to eat and it did not make so very much differ - ence as long as we picked out a variety of the other things and con - tinually used the products of the dairy. It has increased our resist a nee to disease; it has done everything else for us that diet can do in great measure. That there is room for improvement in the diet of in - dividuals I am well aware; that definite and specific advice will in the near future be given to the individual as to the selection of his food, the proportions in which to mix them to obtain the best results, there can be no doubt. The time is not yet here when that can be done, but this is known, that the dairy industry has made us what we are. Let us preserve it if we are to maintain the progress which we have attained. There is no other way that we may remain vigorous, healthful and progressive people than by the continued liberal patronage of the dairy. When I am told, as I have been told assured, that the milk pur - chases in the state of Massachusetts have fallen to the disastrously low point of three-tenths of a quart of milk a day; when I am told that in six or seven large cities in Ohio six months ago the people were pur - chasing seven-tenths of a quart of milk a day per person and that that hi« fallen in aix months to about a Dint* when 1 »"* told that Lhe milk

THIRTY FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 87 liiirihaspo in the city of Chicago have fallen nearly thirty per cent in year or a year and a half: and furthermore, that half a doien of th largest herds in the state of Ohio have been dispersed and many of th animals Hold for slaughter in the last few months, I feel that I must n longer stay at home, but must go out and tell people what the dairy ia clustiy means to them and to see if something cannot be done to stop the decline in the purchase of the products of the dairy. (Applause. It lias made us what we are, gentlemen; it has made us what we are We must take some steps to preserve the dairy industry. I shall be gla to talk over with you what measures may be adopted in order to attai i hat end. 1 thank you. (Applause.) DISCUSSION MK. MINN Mr. Chairman, 1 move you we extend a vote of pro - fouiul thanks to Dr. McCollum for this splendid exposition of the value of our industry and that we do it by a rising vote. Motion seconded. THE CHAIRMAN: You have heard the motion. Those in favor of In- motion please rise. The motion is carried unanimously. DR. McCOLU'M: May I say one word? I will have to catch a 5:30 train and 1 will have to leave here in time to make certain that I get it I want to get all the suggestions from you that I may make use of, that I may be the more useful to the public at this time in tell - ing them the story that I am telling you. I assure you it will stand the test of time. I shall be glad to have any information and suggestions you may give me. MR. MINN I would like to ask one thing. Dr. McCollum; what would you suggest to us as an organized body to do to aid you in this work? DR. McCOLLUM: 1 will be glad to say what I can in regard to that matter. On tne first day of March I went over to Atlantic City to attend a national convention with regard to human economics, of women, and told them essentially the story which I have told you here this after - noon. I am going to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to meet a biennial conven - tion of the National Federation of Women's Clubs and talk to them about it. There seems to be but one line of procedure which can give good results. It is going to take a lot of work to do it. We must put this thing across to the women of this country. They are the ones who look after the purchase of milk; they are the ones who are the moat .sentimental about getting the proper things for their children to eat. If you can tell them and convince them that it is necessary for them to buy the stuff, they are going to buy it. If they don't know about it, if milk seems to them to be the most expensive thing, and batter is high

NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION 88 nn<l cream is high and they nee t lie chaiis hanging up on Iho wall com - inc oul from tin- Food Administi at ion show ins that you ran get tin - cheapest protein in a pound of cereal; thai you can set the rheapes' eneigy in a pound 01 cereal anil ci ttonseed oil. and so forth; and if they believe when tiny see that data that protein and energy are the w marks of an adquate diet, they arc going to go to the grocery store anil buy those things which are cheapest. In other words, they are going to miss it. Th»\ are missing it You ran see it plainly, that they are making a move in that direction. Now, you have got to convince the women of the country that the> must pui chase milk and purchase it liberally; that they must not cease their patronage of the dairy and of its phases of activity. Now. we ran do that in certain ways. You have got to get ahold m those women who have leisure and who have the "pep" to go uot. to l;e lea i!i is in their communities. That is the reason I am going to these women, who are sources oi information to others, and convince them lliat they musl purchase the products of the dairy; that the daily in dustiy is of first importance It is of as much importance as the win ning of this war; and they must purchase mirk. Now. it you can per suade them that that is so, they will do it. The next thing to <!<> is to iomething definite and specific anil very school teacher in the I'niteii sufficiently brief into the hands 01 States, and somebody must reach States and convince her that the s ?very school teacher in the l"nite )iy I have told you here this aftei noon is a bona fide piece of information. She should be instructed t. ask every child in school next year whether he has had his quota oi milk that day. and if he has not that he must go home and tell mother that he won't grow up with a big muscle on his arm unless he does. (Laughter and appplause.) And. if you can get the school teachers of this country to feel that it is their duty to call this matter la the attention of the children in the schools, not once but every day ilur ing nex year, you will achieve your purpose. (Applause.) MR. NEWMAN: Professor, right now. while everybody is talking and trying to do their utmost to follow the rules gotten out by the Food Administration, and the suggestions as well as the rules, and while the lecall of some of their previous rules does not get the attention that the original issue gets, wouldn't it be possible for you who have the ear of Mr. Hoover to call his attention to the fact that the order allowing the use of milk in bread should be given greater publicity? Now. they tell us that that order has been suspended, but the people of this state do not know it. I think it is highly important that they should know it. DR. McCOLLUM: That is a matter of fundamental importance, that we should use a liberal amount of milk in bread. Many people do not care for milk as a beverage; they do not like it. That has nothing to do with their demands for milk. If they do not like it as a beverage it should be put into the foods as prepared, as it has been in the past.

THIKTY-KOI'KTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 89 and our system is built up on a liberal amount of the products of the <tair yand it should continue to be so. I am planning to go lo Washing - ton on Tuesday to see Mr. Hoover about this very thing. (Applause.) MR. Ml'NN: In those two protective substances, what could you supplement in the feed for dairy cows to produce the most of them? DR. McCOLLUM: You have been making a greater success in the feeding of the dairy cow than any other farm animal. The dairy cow lias had her liberal ration of the leafy portion of the plant. She gets both of them in there. And the greatest problem of the dairy cow Is on the mineral element side. MR. Ml'NN: Where does she get her butterfat element, in the leaf? DR. McCOLLUM: She gets that in the leal. They are both in the leal MR. MI'NN: How much milk ought we to say that schoolboy ( ught to have every day? UK McCOLLl'M: I have been asked that question a good many limes. My answer is this: Thai I have four children and 1 give them i quait of milk apiece every day. (Applause.) MR. Hl'NZIKER: There have been reports circulated in the press i hat such treatment as we give the milk and the cream and the butter, such as pasteurization and the neutralization of cream for shipping and i he cold storage of butter, diminishes the vitamine properties of these products. DR. McCOLLl'M- That is all based upon a failure to understand the experimental evidence available. Milk, pasteurized milk, is a per - fectly good food, practically the equivalent — it is not quite the equiva - lent in test, but it is practically the equivalent in nutritive value — of fresh milk. Now, I should stop here to explain why there is so much difference in opinion in regard to the value of pasteurized milk. It is because pasteurized milk has been greatly abused. Milk which is produced under clean surroundings, which is pasteurized and then used, is just as good or practically as good as the fresh articcle. Now, on the other hand, pasteurizaticn does delay the souring of milk. In fact, you tak • a pasteurizaticn plant that is run on model principles, where everything is kept clean, scalded and sterilized and milk will keep for a long time, so far as the taste is concerned, after it is pasteurized. But the process of pasteurization simply kills off the lactic acid: it kills the tubercular organism when present; it kills the diphtheria organism and it kills one other: what is it? A VOICE: Typhoid DR. McCOLLUM: Typhoid. It kills those pathogenic organism*

90 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION which form the greatest reason for the pasteurization of milk. Now. our taste don't detect for a long time the development of pernicious organisms in that milk. So, you take milk that is pasteurized in a clean, nice plant and then bottled and sent out. it is not re-set with lactic acid organisms and it don't re-sour. Now, milk may be kept entirely too many hours before it is con - sumed and in time it will sour. Everybody knows that, because there are certain restive organisms that are not killed by the pasteurization process. Now. it is the use by certain people of old pasteurized milk which has been allowed to become unwholesome that has brought this prejudice in the minds of certain people against pasteurized milk. Pas - teurized milk that is reasonably fresh when pasteurized, used fairly promptly after pasteurization, if kept chilled, is a good, wholesome product. There is no reason why we should not continue pasteuriza lion. The fear of pasteurized milk is in a great measure unfounded. It is simply the abuses of pasteurization, or rather the abuse of the product by pasteurization, which results in ignorance. A VOICE: What is the effect of high degrees of temperature DR. McCOLLUM: Well, I cant tell you, when it gets up that high THE VOICE: The baker's bread is heated up to about 5U0 degree; of temperature. DR. McCOLLUM: Oh. it never gets that high on the inside. 1 think THE VOICE: Not on the inside, but in the oven DR. McCOLLUM: Well, 1 would make the sajne reply to thai, that I would make to this question as to the detraction of these two un - knowns by food that is cooked in an alkaline condition. It is a common practice to cook beans with soda, and when you do you destroy the two unknowns. But, in respect to one of these unknown things, we eat in all our natural food about five times as much of that thing as we actually need to keep us in ordinary health. If you want to eat one ingredient without that, go ahead and do it. there is no reason to get scared about it. If the usable qualities of milk are destroyed in the outer edge of the loaf, well and good, even if it is destroyed absolutely in that portion of the bread which goes into the loaf, it is still an excellent practice to put milk in bread because of the extraordinary value of the milk protein and the corrective action of its mineral content. You get plenty of the unknown substances in the rest of your diet, providing you follow the instructions I have given you. MR. CAMPBELL: Professor McCollum. I understand you are to see Mr. Hoover next week in reard to the breadmaking. I had an inter - view with Mr. Hoover lens than a week ago upon this question and I Khis reasons for the rule and there have been changes, so that as milk M is desired can be used now in breadmaking. That is the

THIRTY-FOURTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 91 new rule. But they have this condition and I wish you would call Mr Hoover's attention to it: They can use as much milk in any form as they please in the making of bread, but they have forbidden the bake to let that be known to the consumer. They cannot advertise that there is any milk in bread nor can they use it as a reason for the sale o the bread. DR. McCOLLUM: Can you tell me why ythat order was given? MR. CAMPBELL: Yes, Mr. Hoover told me that the reason was hat lie was trying to conserve wheat; that he did not want any more wheat used than possible, and if they used this advertising of the milk us an advertisement for the sale of bread that it would increase the use of flour and the very thing that they have tried to discourage. THE CHAIRMAN: I don't think we ought to detain you here any longer. Dr. McCollum.. It is three minutes past five. DR. McCOLLUM: Well, I will have to run along. Any of you gentlemen who want to give ne a suggestion, I should be very glad if you will forthwith put it into writing and address it to me at the Johns Mopkins Medical School in Baltimore and I will be very glad to ac - cumulate such a correspondence with any other information you have that would be of value. I would like to leave this with you. and I want to do everything I can to further the interest tof the dairy industry and give all the assistance I can at any time. I thank you. (Applause, all members standing.) MR. MINN: I want Dr. McCollum to know that he leaves here with the pledge of all of us representing the dairy industry in the varied branches to render him every assistance that lies within our power. (Applause.) The foregoing does not as fully cover the whole subject of milk and its products as Dr. McCollum has on occasion when he has more gener - alized. The following is added from his own store of information be - cause of some questions asked at the Chicago meeting concerning the effec* of pasteurization: "Dr. McCollum. and Drs. usborne and Mendell of Yale, have con - clusively demonstrated that the process of buttermaking does in no way destroy these unknown properties. The heat of pasteurisation does not affect these properties. In experiments butterfat was boiled from two to three hours without showing the slightest effect on the growth - promoting properties. In pasteurization cream is not heated above 180 to 185 degrees Mahrenheit; in fact, most of it is heated only to 145 degrees Fahrenheit, using the holding process. It is obvious that the process of pasteurization employed in the manufacture of butter leaves these growth-promoting properties of the butterfat in normal active con dition, and, since butter contains over 80 per cent of butterfat, this

92 NEBRASKA DAIRYMEN'S ASSOCIATION makes cf it a highly valuable and necessary part of the diet "Fuither. in connection with experiments on cream used in making 1 utter, it was shown that standardization of cream for acid and for fa' does in no way minimize the power of the butterfat to supply tlte es m ntial factors. In fact butterfat was made alkaline in excess so that it foimed a soap, and the feeding of that soap was just as effective in pirmrting growth and curing disease as the feeding of the butterfat n. butter in its original state. "Again, experiments were conducted to determine the effect of .-toragp. at low temperature and at ordinary temperature, on the value ot butter as a growth-promoting, disease-curing food. These experiments clearly demonstrated that even when butter had become rancid, and was otherwise materially deteriorated, its feeding would still have the normal beneficial effect on the rats." MILK AND CREAM SHIPMENTS In compiling the year book for 1918 am certainly rery much pleased to be in a position to give our members information regarding the milk and cream shipments from all stations in Nebraska for the past five years. Since the organization of the Dairy Association the matter of securing definite statistics was one great source of trouble, and dur - ing the year 1913, through the egorts of Mr. S. C. Bassett, who war serving as Secretary and Treasurer and the writer as President, we were successful in submitting a plan to the State Railway Commis - sion to secure this data for us. and it was also ot' use to them in various bearings. They took the matter up with the several railroad and express companies who handled the milk and cream and had them render a monthly statement of the number of cans of milk and cream shipped each month from the stations, and the data was then taken from those reports and compiled by the Secretary of the Association. We have been working on this for the past five years and have ii fn such shape that in printing it in the year book information can br secured that will show the number of cans shipped from every static - in Nebraska every month during the past five years. The information is considered most valuable as it readily shows where the shipments have increased or fallen off during this period and that indicates whether dairying at that point is also on the increase or decrease. Another interesting part of this that is very noticeable is the heavy shipments during the summer months when the price of cream is lowest and the quality poorest and then in the fall gradually decreases as the price advances and during the winter months when the price is the highest the shipments are lowest in the year. At a number of stations, like Mtlford. Elkhorn. Kennard. Benning-

THIRTY FOIRTH ANNUAL CONVENTION 93 ton. Denion. and Springfield, ure heavy milk shipping stations and ship - ments move to Lincoln and Omaha. At other points where the cream shipments are very heavy, many of the large creameries have what is termed branch houses, and cream is shipped into these points locally and weighed, tested and remitted for and then shipped direct to their nearest plant and churned into butter. Some of the more important stations where there are main - tained are Crawford. Norfolk, Falls City, Fairbury. Hastings and Holdrege. In case you would lkie to know how much butter could be made at any ot these stations, just figure out that an average can of cream will make 30 pounds of butter and will not take very long to ascertain just how much butter is made at any one station, or still better go a little further and add together all the cans shipped from all the sta - tions in your county and you will, by multiplying this amount by 30. Una out how much butter could be made in your county if all was churned there. Furthermore, am pleased to be in a position to advise our members that in securing this data and publishing the same we are giving out information tht no other State Dairy Association has ever published and usual Nebraska leads in this. R. W. McGINNIS. Secretary
